The three sets of things that the Buddha: The entire spectrum of noble ethics
How a mendicant is accomplished in ethic: Renouncing the rod and the sword
Living full of compassion for all living beings
Refraining from unworthy branches of knowledge and wrong livelihood
Unworthy branches of knowledge and wrong: Rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations

Administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and binding on herbs
The qualities of a mendicant accomplishe: Living restrained in the monastic code
Conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places
Acting skillfully by body and speech
Being purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct
Guarding the sense doors, having mindfulness and situational awareness, and being content.
How a mendicant guards the sense doors [: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes
When they hear a sound with their ears
When they smell an odor with their nose
When they taste a flavor with their tongue
When they feel a touch with their body
When they know a thought with their mind
How a mendicant has mindfulness and situ: When going out and coming back
When bending and extending the limbs
When bearing the outer robe, bowl, and robes
When eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting
When walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent
How a mendicant is content [dn10:2.1.0]: A mendicant is content with robes to look after the body
A mendicant is content with almsfood to look after the belly
